bibl.title: Letter from [Philip Showalter Hench] to Maria Teresa Loma viuda de Rojas, August 28, 1940

div1.p: [Hench] thanks Rojas for her help. He will send a report to the Cuban government and hopes it will stimulate interest in the memorial. He asks her to mark the Camp Lazear location on maps.

div1.head: Letter from [Philip Showalter Hench] to Maria Teresa Loma viuda de Rojas, August 28, 1940
div1.opener:
Copy to Moran to show Mrs Phillips
August 28, 1940
My dear Senora Rojas:
div1.p:
The other day I wrote you the long letter which I am enclosing,
but have been delayed in sending it to you while awaiting the photographs and maps
to be copies, which I now enclose. In the meantime, I was delighted to receive
your long and courteous note and hasten to express my great appreciation to you,
your daughter and to Senorita Cabrera for your continued help and interest.

Thank you so very much for writing to the Agronomio Station
of Santiago de las Vegas. Please do not bother further about this now. I am
sending the photographs of the two trees to our Forestry Department in Washington,
hoping that someone can, from the photographs, tell me the approximate age of the
framboyant trees. If they cannot, I will bother you again with this matter or I
will write to the Santiago Station myself.

You have been extremely kind in trying to find the newspapers
with the data about Reed and yellow fever. I appreciate so much the notes you have
sent me. They will be very useful. I was anxious to find the Havana Post for
November 24 and 25, 1900, but since the material in your National Library is not
yet in order, we must postpone hunting for the papers, and I will try to see whether
such papers might be in the New York Public Library or the Congressional Library in
Washington. If not, do you think some other library in Cuba, perhaps at Santiago,
might have the Havana papers for 1900?

The photographs I am now sending you will be augmented by
others that I will send you later, and rest assured that my final manuscript will
be submitted to you for your final approval before it is published. As soon as I
hear from you, I plan to send my formal report to the Cuban government, in care of
Dr. Ramos, Secretary of Defense, and Dr. Moya, Secretary of Sanitation. I will send
a copy also to Dr. Albertini and others at the Finlay Institute, and a copy to Mesers.
Moran and Pogolotti. I am sure that we can interest Americans in seeing that some sort
of a memorial is placed on the San Jose farm.

The one thing above all which I am anxious to obtain from you,
is to have you mark as clearly as possible on the enclosed maps, just where you
remember Camp Lazear was in relation to the present houses, street, and quarry.
Will you please mark a X at the approximate center of the camp, and then line out
the approximate dimensions of the camp. Will you please authenticate this by writing
in your own handwriting on the front or the bottom of the map, something as follows:
“This is where the experimental camp was located, on the San Jose farm in 1900. This
was the camp set up by the U. S. Army doctors to carry out their experiments which
proved the cause of yellow fever,” Signed by your full name. (or words to that effect)C
You will realize that this is the most important proof that I can have, and I will have
this map and your drawing and statement photographed and send copies to those inter-
ested in Cuba and in this country.
I cannot tell you how greatly I appreciate your wonderful help.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, - 2 -
P. S. I believe I will need a copy of the original map
of your farm. Was it 1850, or 1857? I will arrange for a photographer to
call on you and copy it, if you will kindly let me do so.
P.S.H.
